name: Paris
intro_vibe: The city of light, love, and endless carbs.

general_info.description: Paris is the capital and most populous city of France. With an official estimated population of 2,102,650 residents as of 1 January 2023 in an area of more than 105 km², Paris is the fourth-most populated city in the European Union and the 30th most densely populated city in the world.

weather_breakdown.name: January
pros: Very few tourists, shorter lines everywhere
Post-holiday sales (les soldes) offer major discounts
Great crisp winter light for atmospheric photography
cons: Cold, grey, and damp weather common
weather_breakdown.clothing: Pack a heavy coat, scarf, waterproof shoes, and a compact umbrella.

weather_breakdown.name: February
cons: Cold snaps with biting wind near the Seine
weather_breakdown.clothing: Bring a windproof coat, warm hat, and an insulating mid-layer.

weather_breakdown.name: March
pros: Early spring flowers and increasing daylight
Streets feel livelier as winter ends
cons: Unpredictable weather—sun one moment, rain the next
Some terraces remain closed early in the month
weather_breakdown.clothing: Layer a light jacket with a warm mid-layer and carry a small umbrella.

weather_breakdown.name: April
pros: Terraces reopen and walking conditions are ideal
Moderate crowds compared to peak summer
weather_breakdown.clothing: Wear layers, a waterproof jacket, and comfortable walking shoes.

weather_breakdown.name: May
pros: Long days with perfect terrace weather
Lively outdoor events, markets, and picnics
Ideal weather for exploring on foot
cons: Hotel and restaurant bookings fill quickly
Occasional sudden warm days require sun protection
weather_breakdown.clothing: Pack breathable layers, a sunhat, and a light sweater for evenings.

weather_breakdown.name: June
pros: Long golden evenings and early summer festivals
Great atmosphere along the Seine after work hours
weather_breakdown.clothing: Bring breathable fabrics, a light evening jacket, and sun protection.

weather_breakdown.name: July
pros: Bastille Day fireworks and peak festival season
Perfect weather for river picnics and evening walks
cons: Peak crowds and heavy metro usage
weather_breakdown.clothing: Wear very lightweight clothing, a sunhat, and comfortable sandals.

weather_breakdown.name: August
pros: Quieter local streets as Parisians leave for holidays
Great time to explore smaller museums
cons: Some restaurants and boutiques close for vacances
weather_breakdown.clothing: Pack light summer clothes with a thin evening layer.

weather_breakdown.name: September
pros: Fantastic walking weather with moderate crowds
City feels revived after summer holidays
cons: Fashion Week can spike prices and make reservations harder
weather_breakdown.clothing: Wear smart-casual layers and a light rain jacket.

weather_breakdown.name: October
pros: Cozy café and bistro season begins
cons: Cooler, wetter days require waterproof shoes
weather_breakdown.clothing: Bring warm mid-layers, a scarf, and waterproof shoes.

weather_breakdown.name: November
pros: New cultural seasons, exhibitions, and theatre
Cozy cafés perfect for slow afternoons
weather_breakdown.clothing: Pack a warm coat, hat, umbrella, and layered outfits.

weather_breakdown.name: December
pros: Holiday lights and Christmas markets everywhere
cons: Busy travel periods around Christmas and New Year
weather_breakdown.clothing: Wear thermal layers, a heavy winter coat, gloves, and insulated shoes.

etiquette_tips: Always greet with a simple "Bonjour" before any request – it's a social reset button. If someone answers "Bonsoir" instead, it's not a correction; it's just them matching the time of day.
Lower your volume – speaking softly in cafés, metros, and queues is considered respectful and adult-like in France.
Never say "Garçon!" to a waiter. A polite "Excusez-moi" with eye contact is the correct Parisian way to get service.
Don't rush meals. Eating on the go is uncommon; sit down, even for a quick coffee, as lingering is part of Parisian rhythm.
Bread is placed directly on the tablecloth, not on your plate. Using it to gently 'push' food onto your fork is normal.
In boutiques, avoid touching merchandise excessively without permission, especially in designer stores. Ask first: "Je peux regarder ?"
Queue discipline matters – join the line directly and avoid bypassing others subtly. Parisians notice instantly.
Small talk with strangers is unusual. Polite but minimal interaction is the norm unless you're in a friendly neighborhood café.
When entering a building’s elevator or lobby, greeting others with a soft "Bonjour" is expected and prevents awkwardness.
Tipping is not mandatory but appreciated. Leaving €1–€2 for good service in cafés or rounding up is perfectly Parisian.

etiquette_tips: The 'Bonjour' Rule: Always say Bonjour when entering a shop. It is not optional.
Dining Pace: Meals are slow. You must ask for the bill ('L'addition').
Volume: Keep your voice down in public and on the Metro.
Dress Code: Smart casual. No gym clothes for dinner.
Escalators: Stand on the RIGHT, walk on the LEFT.

neighborhoods.name: Le Marais
neighborhoods.description: A historic district blending medieval streets with cutting-edge boutiques and cafés. Its Jewish heritage, LGBTQ+ culture, and art galleries give it a layered, cosmopolitan energy while still feeling intimate and walkable.

neighborhoods.name: Montmartre
neighborhoods.description: Home of bohemian Paris, perched above the city with sweeping panoramic views. The village-like streets, artists’ studios, and old cabarets make it one of the most atmospheric places to wander at sunset.

neighborhoods.name: Latin Quarter
neighborhoods.description: Built around the Sorbonne, this area mixes centuries-old universities with lively bars and affordable eateries. It's youthful, intellectual, and full of bookshops and classic Parisian cafés.

neighborhoods.name: Saint-Germain-des-Prés
neighborhoods.description: The spiritual home of Parisian café culture and philosophy. You’ll find refined boutiques, art galleries, and historic cafés where writers like Sartre and Beauvoir shaped modern thinking.

neighborhoods.name: Canal Saint-Martin
neighborhoods.description: A relaxed, youthful neighborhood centered around a leafy canal where locals picnic, drink wine, and watch the bridges swing open. It's filled with independent cafés, vintage stores, and street art.

neighborhoods.name: Palais Royal / 1st
neighborhoods.description: One of the most refined corners of Paris, home to manicured gardens, arcades, and stylish boutiques. Despite being near major tourist spots, it feels calm, geometric, and perfectly Parisian.

neighborhoods.name: Batignolles
neighborhoods.description: A residential neighborhood popular with young families, filled with organic bakeries, wine bars, and a local weekend market. It has a quiet but stylish charm and feels like a true Parisian enclave.

neighborhoods.name: Montorgueil
neighborhoods.description: A pedestrianized neighborhood centered around one of Paris’s best food streets. Bakeries, cheese shops, cafés, and seafood counters create a bustling, delicious microcosm of Parisian gastronomy.

neighborhoods.name: Gros Caillou
neighborhoods.description: The quiet residential area right behind the Eiffel Tower, far calmer than the tourist side. Filled with elegant streets, independent bakeries, and charming cafés favored by well-off locals.

neighborhoods.name: Belleville
neighborhoods.description: A multicultural neighborhood blending Chinese, North African, and French influences with a gritty artistic edge. Known for street art, cheap eats, and steep streets with dramatic city views.

neighborhoods.name: Oberkampf
neighborhoods.description: One of Paris’s most energetic going-out districts, packed with bars and live music. By day it's relaxed and creative; by night it becomes a hotspot for young Parisians.

neighborhoods.name: République
neighborhoods.description: A major crossroads of Parisian life with big boulevards, cafés, and metro connections everywhere. It's lively, democratic, and often the site of public gatherings and cultural events.

culture.name: Le Marais
culture.description: Tight cobbled streets, hôtels particuliers, and a mix of Jewish heritage and LGBTQ+ nightlife.

culture.name: Montmartre
culture.description: Perched on a hill, it retains a village atmosphere with artists, vineyards, and winding streets.

culture.name: Latin Quarter
culture.description: Home to the Sorbonne, filled with bookshops, student cafes, and medieval history.

culture.name: Saint-Germain
culture.description: Famous for historic literary cafes like Les Deux Magots and high-end galleries.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: The Metro is the lifeline of Paris. Cheap, fast, and everywhere.
details: The Metro: 16 lines covering the whole city. Buy a Navigo Easy pass.
Walking: Paris is very walkable. You can cross the center in 40 mins.
RER: Faster trains for crossing the city and reaching airports (CDG/Orly).
Etiquette: Let people off before you get on. Don't block doors.

logistics.title: Scams to Avoid
logistics.summary: Avoid the Ring Scam and the Bracelet Scam to stay safe.
details: The Gold Ring: Someone 'finds' a ring and tries to give it to you for money. Ignore them.
The Bracelet: Men at Sacré-Cœur try to tie a string on your finger. Keep hands in pockets.
The Petition: Kids asking for signatures for 'deaf/mute' causes. It's a pickpocket distraction.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: Paris is safe, but pickpockets are skilled. Watch your phone.
details: Pickpockets: Active on Metro Line 1 and near Eiffel Tower.
Phones: Don't leave them on cafe tables. Don't use them near metro doors.
Night: Most areas are safe, but avoid unlit parks after dark.

logistics.title: Apps to Download
logistics.summary: These apps will make your trip smoother.
details: CityMapper: The absolute best for transit navigation.
TheFork (LaFourchette): Great for restaurant bookings and discounts.
G7 Taxi: The official Paris taxi app (better/safer than Uber in some areas).
Google Translate: Download the French offline pack.

must_eat.description: A symbol of the Parisian morning ritual. True croissants are made with pure butter and hand-laminated dough that creates flaky, honeycombed layers. Parisians buy them early and eat them warm, often standing at the bar with a coffee. A straight croissant usually indicates higher-quality butter; curved ones can signal margarine. Locals tear them by hand—never cut—and often dip in café crème.

A twice-daily ritual for Parisians. The legally protected “baguette de tradition” can only include flour, water, yeast, and salt—no additives, no freezing. Its thin crust should crackle like paper, and the interior is open and irregular. Parisians tear pieces by hand and pair them with butter, cheese, or simply eat them on the walk home.

The Paris bistro is a cultural stage: mirrored walls, chalkboard menus, and tightly packed tables that encourage eavesdropping. Signature dishes—steak-frites, confit de canard, boeuf bourguignon—reflect comfort and heritage. Bread arrives unrequested and the pace is unhurried. Splitting the bill individually is considered un-Parisian; order, talk, linger.

Paris runs on cafés—part living room, part office, part observation deck. Order “un café” for a simple espresso, “un crème” for a milky coffee, or “un noisette” for a small espresso with a touch of warm milk. Terrace seating costs more but offers the true Paris pastime: people-watching. Nursing a single drink for an hour is perfectly normal.

France’s 400+ cheeses represent its regional pride. In Paris, fromageries curate seasonal selections: Brie de Meaux (soft), Comté 24-month (hard), Chèvre frais (fresh goat), Roquefort (blue). Cheese is served after the main dish and before dessert—never cold. Learn the cutting etiquette: maintain the shape of the wedge and never blunt the “nose.”

A French pâtisserie icon, refined and colorful. The perfect macaron has a smooth shell, delicate ‘feet,’ and a chewy almond interior sandwiching flavored ganache. Though available everywhere, Paris elevates it into art. Popular flavors include pistachio, salted caramel, rose, and seasonal fruit. Light, portable, and ideal for the Translation Bridge feature.

A quintessential brasserie dish: pan-seared beef with a mound of hand-cut fries. Sauces vary—béarnaise, peppercorn, or simply butter and salt. In Paris, fries are usually thin and crisp, and the default cooking level (‘cuisson’) skews rarer than in many countries. Ask for ‘à point’ for medium.

Wine in Paris is a cultural language. Bistros offer glasses (‘vin au verre’) or house carafes (‘une carafe’). Natural wine bars showcase unfiltered, biodynamic bottles from tiny producers. Common terms: ‘rouge’ (red), ‘blanc’ (white), ‘rosé,’ ‘sec’ (dry). The apéritif and post-meal digestif are cherished rituals.

must_see.description: The Eiffel Tower is best experienced early in the morning before tour groups arrive or late at night when it sparkles every hour. Skip the long elevator queue by taking the stairs to the 2nd floor—faster, cheaper, and with more satisfying views. For photos, avoid the overcrowded Champ de Mars and instead shoot from Rue de l’Université or Trocadéro just after sunrise. Locals rarely go to the summit; the 2nd floor offers a more balanced panorama. For the nighttime sparkle, stand on Pont d’Iéna for perfect symmetry without the chaos. Avoid visiting on heavily foggy winter days unless you enjoy a moody, atmospheric look.

The Louvre is enormous, so treat it as an experience rather than a checklist. Enter through the underground Carrousel du Louvre entrance to avoid the Pyramid crowds, and visit on Wednesday or Friday evenings when the museum stays open late and becomes dramatically quieter. If you want to see Mona Lisa, go straight at opening or during the final hour. Instead of the famous hits, explore the Richelieu Wing for Vermeer’s masterpieces and the peaceful Cour Marly and Cour Puget. These bright sculpture courtyards feel like secret sanctuaries in the middle of Paris. Plan two to three hours, not an entire day.

Even during restoration, Notre-Dame remains one of the most impressive Gothic façades in Europe. The best angle is from Square René Viviani during golden hour, when light hits the flying buttresses on the southern side. The rear of the cathedral, with its intricate stonework, is often more beautiful than the front. Walk along the Seine’s quiet quays behind the apse where locals gather at sunset with wine. Avoid mid-day when tour groups crowd the area and instead aim for early morning or late evening for a calmer, almost spiritual atmosphere.

Sacré-Cœur offers one of the best free panoramas in Paris. Skip the crowded front staircase—where bracelet scammers operate—and approach from Rue du Chevalier-de-La-Barre for a calmer, more cinematic entry. Early mornings have a soft mist over the city, while sunsets are warm but crowded. After visiting the basilica, wander the side streets of Montmartre to escape the tourist crush around Place du Tertre. Rue Norvins, Rue de l’Abreuvoir, and leafy Villa Léandre offer postcard-perfect scenes of old Paris that locals still adore.

Musée d’Orsay is home to the world’s best Impressionist collection, displayed under soaring iron-and-glass architecture. Head straight to the top floor at opening time to enjoy Monet, Degas, and Renoir in quiet rooms before they fill. Don’t miss the iconic giant clock window overlooking the Seine—it’s one of Paris’s most photogenic spots. Tickets should be booked online as queues can stretch beyond 45 minutes in peak season. The museum is compact enough to explore in two hours, but the building itself deserves time to admire.

A serene sculpture sanctuary loved by locals. The garden alone—home to The Thinker, The Gates of Hell, and sunlit lawns—offers a peaceful alternative to the Louvre’s crowds. Inside the 18th-century mansion, Rodin’s plaster casts and studies reveal his creative process in rare detail. Visit on a weekday morning for near silence, or in summer when the café terrace becomes one of Paris’s calmest spots for coffee under the trees. This is one of the city’s most intimate museums, perfect for slow, reflective visits.

A Gothic jewel box filled with 13th-century stained glass that glows like floating colors. The upper chapel, with its soaring windows, is the highlight and best seen mid-afternoon when sunlight makes the reds and blues shimmer. Arrive at opening to avoid long queues; lines often exceed an hour by mid-day. Combine with a visit to the nearby Conciergerie for a powerful look into medieval Paris. Even repeat visitors are stunned by how otherworldly the light feels here.

Canal Saint-Martin is one of the best places to experience real, everyday Paris. In the evenings, locals gather along the water with wine, and the mood is relaxed and communal. Early mornings offer calm reflections and quiet streets perfect for photography. Wander Quai de Valmy, Rue Bichat, and the iron footbridges for cinematic angles. Cafés in the area are creative and independent, making it a great neighborhood to explore before or after sunset. Avoid late weekend nights if you prefer quiet.

One of Paris’s most dramatic parks, built over a former gypsum quarry. Expect jagged cliffs, lakes, waterfalls, and steep pathways that feel unlike anywhere else in the city. Climb to the Temple de la Sibylle for panoramic skyline views. Early mornings are magical—mist hangs low, joggers pass quietly, and the park feels like a hidden micro-world far from central Paris. Perfect for picnics, slow walks, and photography sessions.

Paris’s covered passages are 19th-century arcades filled with antique bookstores, marble floors, ornate ironwork, and warm café lights. Begin at Passage des Panoramas and wander toward Galerie Vivienne—one of the city’s most elegant interiors with mosaic floors and a glass roof. These passages are perfect on rainy days or early mornings when you can enjoy near-empty corridors. Each one feels like a preserved time capsule of old Paris, ideal for slow exploration.

One of the world’s most opulent opera houses, with marble staircases, gold-leaf balconies, and the famous Marc Chagall ceiling above the auditorium. Daytime visits are beautiful, but nighttime performances make the building glow. A secret trick: buy a last-minute reduced-price ticket just to access the interior, even if your seat has no view. Wander the Grand Foyer, which feels like a mirrored Versailles hall, and admire the sweeping staircase where Parisians once displayed their finest fashion.

Pont Alexandre III is Paris's most ornate bridge, decorated with gold statues, Art Nouveau lamps, and sweeping views of the Seine. The bridge is especially photogenic at sunrise when the light reflects off its gilded sculptures, and at sunset when the Eiffel Tower glows in the background. Walk toward Invalides for lesser-known angles that avoid crowds. A top spot for cinematic photoshoots, romantic strolls, and golden-hour skyline views.

A refined Parisian garden where locals come to read, jog, debate, and sunbathe. The Medici Fountain is a highlight, especially in the morning when soft light filters through the trees. The iconic green chairs can be moved anywhere, so grab a pastry and pick your perfect spot by the pond. Quiet, elegant, and surprisingly large, the garden is both a neighborhood hangout and one of the city’s most beautiful green spaces. Ideal for slow afternoons.

The original elevated walkway that inspired New York’s High Line. This long green path runs above the city, offering unusual perspectives, quiet alcoves, and pockets of nature suspended above the streets. Best visited mid-morning or in spring when plants are in full bloom. The raised views of Parisian rooftops and hidden courtyards make it one of the city’s most peaceful walks, especially for photographers looking for more creative compositions.

A pastel-colored residential street that has become one of Paris’s most photographed locations. Each house is painted a different shade, giving the street a storybook charm. Visit early in the morning to avoid crowds and to be respectful to the residents who live here. The cobblestones, vibrant façades, and seasonal flowers make this a quick yet memorable photo stop, perfect after exploring nearby Gare de Lyon or the banks of the Seine.

must_eat.description: The quintessential French breakfast staple. A true croissant au beurre is made with pure butter (not margarine), creating its characteristic flaky, golden layers. Look for the curved shape (vs. the straight 'croissant ordinaire'). Best enjoyed warm from the bakery in the morning.
The daily ritual. Look for 'Tradition' on the sign—it means no additives allowed by law. The perfect baguette has a golden, crackly crust and a soft, airy interior. Locals buy them twice daily.
A simple but perfect baguette sandwich with high-quality Parisian ham and salted butter. It is the true on-the-go lunch of locals, selling over a billion units a year.
A delicate almond-based confection filled with ganache or buttercream. While available everywhere, specialized boutiques like Pierre Hermé and Ladurée are the benchmarks for texture and flavor.

The ultimate French comfort food: a hot sandwich made with ham and cheese, topped with béchamel sauce and grated cheese, then grilled until bubbling. Add a fried egg on top to make it a 'Croque-Madame'.
A cultural institution characterized by zinc-topped bars and handwritten menus. Classic dishes include boeuf bourguignon and pot-au-feu. Service is fast and efficient.
The classic bistro dish: a seared steak (often sirloin or entraña) served with crisp, thin French fries and Béarnaise or pepper sauce. Order it 'saignant' (rare) for the best flavor.
A deeply caramelized onion broth topped with a slice of toasted bread and a generous layer of melted Comté or Gruyère cheese. A warming classic often eaten late at night.
Served after the main course and before dessert. Know the progression: fresh (chèvre), soft (Brie), hard (Comté), and blue (Roquefort).
An essential part of the meal's rhythm. House wine by the carafe is common and affordable. Paris is currently experiencing a massive 'Natural Wine' boom.
Where locals spend hours over a single espresso. Seating is strategic: 'en terrasse' (outside) costs more than inside. People-watching is the primary activity.
Beloved street food ranging from sweet (Nutella, sugar) to savory buckwheat galettes (sarrasin). Best enjoyed from a walk-up window (guichet).
A choux pastry filled with vanilla, chocolate, or coffee cream and topped with a glossy fondant glaze. Modern pâtisseries offer colorful seasonal variations.
A small caramelized cake with a dark, thick crust and a soft, custardy center flavored with rum and vanilla. Originally from Bordeaux but now a staple in Paris.
